questions.explanation: `var` declarations are hoisted to the top of their scope and initialized with `undefined`. So when `console.log(a)` runs, `a` exists but hasn't been assigned 10 yet.

`var` has function scope, not block scope. By the time the setTimeout callbacks execute, the loop has finished and `i` is 3 for all callbacks. Using `let` instead would create a new binding for each iteration.
The `+` operator concatenates when one operand is a string, resulting in "11". The `-` operator only works with numbers, so JavaScript coerces the string to a number, resulting in 0.
Synchronous code runs first (A, D). Promises (microtasks) have higher priority than setTimeout (macrotasks), so C runs before B, even though both have 0 delay.
When `greet` is called as a standalone function, `this` refers to the global object (or undefined in strict mode), not `obj`. To preserve context, you could use `obj.greet()` or bind the function.
The function executes synchronously until the first `await`. Then it yields control back to the event loop. "3" prints from the main thread, then the promise resolves and "2" prints.
The push() method adds an element to the end of the array and returns the new length. The array now contains [1, 2, 3, 4], so the length is 4.

questions.code:
const { a, b, c } = { a: 1, b: 2 };
console.log(c);
questions.explanation: When destructuring, if a property doesn't exist in the source object, the variable is assigned `undefined`. Since there's no `c` property in the object, `c` becomes undefined.
`==` allows type coercion, so 0 == false is true. `===` checks both type and value, so 0 !== false.
Arrow functions don't have their own `this`; they use lexical `this` (global). Normal methods bind `this` to the object.
`map` returns a new array and does not mutate the original array.
Synchronous code runs first, then microtasks (Promises), then macrotasks (setTimeout).
Spread operator creates a shallow copy. Changing `copy.a` does not affect `obj.a`.
Closures allow the inner function to remember variables from its outer scope even after the outer function has executed.
Objects are assigned by reference. Both `a` and `b` point to the same object.
Async functions always return a Promise. `.then()` runs after the synchronous code completes.
Function declarations are hoisted with their full definition.
`var` is hoisted but the function assignment is not.
`let` is block scoped.
`var` is function scoped, not block scoped.
All objects (including arrays) are truthy.
Loose equality triggers type coercion.
`null` and `undefined` are equal with `==` but not `===`.
Setting length to 0 clears the array.
Arrays are objects in JavaScript.
Microtasks run before macrotasks.
Default parameters are used when arguments are missing.
`var` is hoisted but not initialized.
Arrow functions inherit `this` from the surrounding scope.
Skipped elements are ignored.
String concatenation happens first, then numeric subtraction.
`let` creates a new binding per iteration.
Frozen objects cannot be mutated.
Thrown errors in async functions reject the promise.
Rest operator collects arguments into an array.
NaN is not equal to anything, even itself.
`Object.is` correctly compares NaN.
Functions inherit from Function.prototype.
Plain objects inherit from Object.prototype.
`b` still holds the reference.
`forEach` returns undefined.
`map` returns a new array.
Block scoped `let` shadows outer variable.
Undefined values are omitted in JSON.
Undefined properties are lost.
`delete` removes the property.
